dialogs.text:
The horrific legacy of slavery remains with us today. Its effects can still be felt in racism in our society.

 

Image credit: Remco de Waal / ANP
dialogs.answer: His Majesty King Willem-Alexander, speaking in Amsterdam on 1 July 2023 at the annual Keti Koti Festival. Keti Koti, which translates to ‘the chains are broken’, is a festival that celebrates the emancipation of enslaved people.

dialogs.text: In many nations the effects of slavery past, -which in essence is taking away human dignity of people who look different from you-, are deep.  Slavery is not something from the past, the structures of unequalness based on race and colour still go on. We see that in a lack of equal chances, in patterns of discrimination and racism and in feelings, often even unconscious, of superiority and inferiority.  These long-rooted patterns of exclusion prevent us from finding solutions for the challenges we are facing today.
dialogs.answer: Ms. Kathleen Ferrier, Chair of the Netherlands National Commission of UNESCO, giving the opening speech for the poster presentation exhibit (adapted from Rijksmuseum’s Slavery) at the UN Office in Geneva on 22 June 2023.
